member.name: T:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager
member.summary: Class used to manage an undo/redo history.

remarks.p: The UndoManager manages the undo and redo history. Operations are added to the undo/redo history by adding instances to it using one of the available methods. One can create an instance of a custom UndoUnit derived class or one of the classes included in this assembly and use the method. The UndoManager also exposes a number of helper methods that will create an UndoUnit and add it to the history. The AddPropertyChange overloads can be used to record the change of a property of some object. The AddCollectionChange overloads can be used to record a change to an collection implementing ICollection>T<. The remaining AddChange overloads may be used to provide a set of delegates representing the Undo and Redo actions that should be taken when the manager is performing an undo or redo operation. These methods using the so if you want to change the UndoUnit type that is created by these methods you may derive a class from and set the property to an instance of that class.

The and are read-only collections of instances. UndoHistoryItem exposes the root that represents the operation to be performed as well as short and long descriptions of the operation. These collections implement INotifyCollectionChanged and therefore can be used in your UI as the source for menu, etc. that would display the history to the end user.

The and methods are used to perform an undo or redo operation. When these methods are invoked a is removed from the associated history (e.g. UndoHistory) and then the method of the is invoked. It is important to realize that by default UndoUnits are not automatically moved to the opposite history. For example, while undoing a property change it is expected that the property change will result in a new call to the AddPropertyChange overload. That would create a new undo unit representing that change and add it to the UndoManager's history. In that case, since the UndoManager was in the process of performing an undo, the new UndoUnit would be added to the redo history.

The UndoManager exposes a number of read-only boolean properties which indicate the current state of the object. The and are true while performing an undo or redo respectively. The and properties indicate if there are any items in the undo/redo history.

When performing discrete initialization, one can use the method to temporarily disable logging of the UndoUnits in the history. Any calls to AddChange are ignored until the method is invoked. The Resume method must be invoked once for each time that the Suspend method is invoked. The property will return true between the calls to Suspend and Resume.

The UndoManager provides support for merging of a new UndoUnit with the most recent UndoUnit that was stored. This is useful in cases where the same action is occuring multiple times. For example while dragging the thumb of a Slider and therefore the property that is bound to the Slider's Value. Merging may be disabled indefinitely by setting the to false. One can also suppress the merging of the current item by invoking the method.

When multiple operations should be treated as a single undoable action, one can use transactions. The UndoManager provides support for transactions using the method. This returns a instance. Any subsequent units that are added to the UndoManager are stored within that transaction until the transaction has been committed (see ) or rolled back (see . Nested transactions are supported so calling StartTransaction while a transaction is progress will add that to the of the . One can get access to the current open transaction, if there is one, using the property. Also, if there is a block of code that you want to execute within a transaction, you may use the method. This method will take care of calling the Rollback method of the transaction it creates if an exception occurs (without preventing the exception from bubbling up). Otherwise it will invoke the Commit of the transaction. When the has been committed it is then added to the undo or redo history depending on the current state of the UndoManager.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new

member.name: M:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.AddChange(Infragistics.Undo.UndoUnit)
member.summary: Adds an to the history.
member.param: The unit to add to the history.

remarks.p: This overload takes the provided and adds it to either the undo or redo history stack based on the current state of the UndoManager. For example while executing an Undo (i.e. is true), change units will be added to the redo stack.

Note: An undo unit is not automatically moved from the undo stack to the redo stack or vice versa. It is expected that either the change that the UndoUnit makes (e.g. a property change) will result in a new change being added to the UndoManager or that the unit itself will add a unit (even itself) to the UndoManager. The is one such example of the latter. The UndoUnit created by that overload will add itself back into the UndoManager if the associated undo or redo delegate is successful.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.AddChange(System.String,System.String,System.Func{Infragistics.Undo.UndoExecuteContext,System.Boolean},System.Func{Infragistics.Undo.UndoExecuteContext,System.Boolean},System.Object)
member.summary: Adds an to the history.
member.param: The general description for the transaction.
The detailed description for the transaction.
The method to invoke when an Undo is being performed
The method to invoke when an Redo is being performed
An optional parameter that represents the object that will be affected by the operation.

remarks.p: This overload creates an undo unit that will execute the when an Undo operation is being performed and will execute the when a Redo operation is being performed. If the operation is successful (i.e. the method returns true) the UndoUnit will add itself back into the history.

Note: Since an explicit description is passed in, the string should be applicable to both undo and redo operations. For example one might use "Bold" or "Toggle Bold" instead of "Enable Bold"/"Disable Bold" since the latter might not be correct if the change is being created for the redo stack. If you do want to use a string specific to the context then you might decide which description to provide by evaluating the property.

member.exception: The 'undoMethod' and 'redoMethod' parameters cannot be null.

remarks.p: Note: This method does not affect the current open if there is one. If you want to stop that transaction you would invoke its or method.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.RegisterReference(System.Object)
member.summary: Used to associate an object with a given

remarks.p: Registering an object with an UndoManager allows a reference to the object to be passed to static methods that are used to obtain the UndoManager with which an undo operation should be registered. This allows an object to not have to store a reference to the UndoManager directly.

member.param: The object with which to associate this UndoManager instance

member.summary: Removes all the matching instances from the and collections.
member.param: The delegate to invoke with each to determine if it should be removed.
Indicates whether the method should affect the current open if there is one.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.Resume
member.summary: Resumes the recording of instances in the history.

remarks.p: The method is meant to be used to temporarily prevent recording of undo operations. This can be helpful when initializing objects/collections before they will be manipulated by the end user. The Resume method must be called to remove the suspension and must be called an equal number of times that the Suspend method is invoked.
While suspended, calls to will be ignored. Also any calls to or will result in an exception.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.StartTransaction(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Used to start a new transaction that will group one or more actions.
member.param: The general description for the transaction.
The detailed description for the transaction.
member.returns: The transaction that was created.

remarks.p: A transaction is used to group one or more instances into a single item in the undo/redo history. The StartTranaction method is used to start a new transaction. If no transactions have been started or all tranasactions are closed, this will create a new root level transaction that is exposed via the . If a transaction has already been started, and therefore RootTransaction returns non-null, the new transaction will be a nested transaction of the leaf open transaction within that . The method returns the newly started transaction.
Note: The and methods cannot be invoked while a transaction is open but one can create transactions while performing an undo/redo operation to gather the operations into a single unit.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.Suspend
member.summary: Suspends the recording of instances in the history.

remarks.p: The Suspend method is meant to be used to temporarily prevent recording of undo operations. This can be helpful when initializing objects/collections before they will be manipulated by the end user. The method must be called to remove the suspension and must be called an equal number of times that the Suspend method is invoked.
While suspended, calls to will be ignored. Also any calls to or will result in an exception.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.UnregisterReference(System.Object)
member.summary: Used to remove an registration for an object that was registered with this UndoManager instance via the method.
member.param: The object with that was previously registered with this UndoManager instance

member.name: M:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.Undo(System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs one or more undo operations from the current history.
member.param: The number of operations in the undo history to execute

member.name: P:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.AllowMerging
member.summary: Returns or sets a boolean indicating if the method may be used to merge changes.

remarks.p: Note: The method is only invoked when 2 or more new UndoUnits are added to the history. If an Undo or Redo operation is performed, the method will not be invoked until after the next non-undo/redo operation is performed.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.CanRedo
member.summary: Returns a boolean indicating if there is an operation that can be redone.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.CanUndo
member.summary: Returns a boolean indicating if there is an operation that can be undone.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.IsPerformingUndo
member.summary: Returns a boolean indicating if the manager is performing an undo operation.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.IsSuspended
member.summary: Returns a boolean indicating if the recording of instances in the history has been suspended using the method.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.MergeTimeout
member.summary: Returns the amount of time since the last operation that a will be allowed.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.RedoHistory
member.summary: Returns a read-only collection of the items in the redo history.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.RootTransaction
member.summary: Returns the outermost current open transaction or null if there is currently no transaction open.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.TopRedoHistoryItem
member.summary: Returns the next item on the top of the

remarks.p: This property returns the at the top of the stack and is therefore equivalent to accessing RedoHistory[0]. The primary use case for this property is for binding such as when displaying the for the tooltip of an Redo button in the UI to avoid the exception information in the output window.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.TopUndoHistoryItem
member.summary: Returns the next item on the top of the

remarks.p: This property returns the at the top of the stack and is therefore equivalent to accessing UndoHistory[0]. The primary use case for this property is for binding such as when displaying the for the tooltip of an Undo button in the UI to avoid the exception information in the output window.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.UndoLimit
member.summary: Returns or sets the maximum number of items to maintain within the undo/redo history.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Undo.UndoManager.UndoHistory
member.summary: Returns a read-only collection of the items in the undo history.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Collections.WeakDictionary`2.ExpandCollapseHelper(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Expands or contracts the size of storage based on the new count after an operation, like add, remove or clear, is performed.
member.param: Specifies that the storage should only be expanded, and not contracted.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Collections.WeakDictionary`2.Add(`0,`1)
member.summary: Adds an entry to the dictionary. If an entry with the specified key already exists, this method throws an exception.
member.param: Key of the entry to add.
Value to associate with the key.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Collections.WeakDictionary`2.Clear
member.summary: Removes all entries from the dictionary.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Collections.WeakDictionary`2.Compact(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Removes entries from the dictionary where keys are no longer alive (have been garbage collected). Note that keys can get garbage collected during the process of compacting and therefore it's not guarrenteed that all the entries in the dictionary will be with live keys after this operation is completed.
member.param: Whether to also remove entries where value is null or has been garbage collected.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Collections.WeakDictionary`2.ContainsKey(`0)
member.summary: Returns true if an entry with the specified key exists in the dictionary.
member.param: Key to check for existence.
member.returns: Returns true if an entry with the specified key exists in the dictionary.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Collections.WeakDictionary`2.Remove(`0)
member.summary: Removes the entry with the specified key. Does nothing if the specified key doesn't exist.
member.param: Key of the entry to remove.
member.returns: True if an entry was removed. False if entry with the specified key was not found.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Collections.WeakDictionary`2.TryGetValue(`0,`1@)
member.summary: Gets the value associated with the specified key. If the entry doesn't exist, returns false.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Collections.WeakDictionary`2.Item(`0)
member.summary: Gets or sets the value associated with the specified key. Set will add an entry for the key if it doesn't already exist.
member.param: Value associated with this key will be returned.
member.returns: Value associated with the specified key.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Collections.WeakDictionary`2.Count
member.summary: Returns the number of entries in the dictionary. Note that this will not take into account any garbage collected items - they will be included in the count.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Collections.WeakDictionary`2.Keys
member.summary: Returns the keys in the dictionary. Only keys with non-null values are returned.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Collections.WeakDictionary`2.Values
member.summary: Returns the values in the dictionary. Only values with non-null keys are returned.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Collections.WeakDictionary`2.System#Collections#Generic#IDictionary{TKey@TValue}#Keys
member.summary: Returns the keys in the dictionary.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Collections.WeakDictionary`2.System#Collections#Generic#IDictionary{TKey@TValue}#Values
member.summary: Returns the values in the dictionary.
